body.p: Some raster (pixels, not vector) images may have a default resolution, set by the designer, using a image editing software. Usually the image size and resolution are set to look best on the screen. The advantage of a resolution set into the image itself it is that it will have the same effective size on the screen and on paper. For example, if the image has 144 dots in width, and an embedded resolution of 72dpi, it will be two inches on screen and on paper.

The problems start to arise when the resolution is not set in the image, and the PDF processor has to decide what resolution to use in order to determine the size of the graphic. In order to solve this, the processor extracts the DPI from:

ol.li: The image-resolution CSS property associated to the element that contains the image.
The built-in fallback resolution of 96 DPI.
